dt: {bc}one who accepts and assists in spreading the {d_link|doctrines|doctrine} of another: such as
{bc}one of the twelve in the inner circle of Christ's followers according to the Gospel accounts
{bc}a convinced {d_link|adherent|adherent:1} of a school or individual

{bc}a member of the Disciples of Christ founded in the U.S. in 1809 that holds the Bible alone to be the rule of faith and practice, usually baptizes by {d_link|immersion|immersion}, and has a congregational {dx_def}see {dxt|congregational||3}{/dx_def} polity

pt: {sc}follower{/sc} {sc}adherent{/sc} {sc}disciple{/sc} {sc}partisan{/sc} mean one who gives full loyalty and support to another. {sc}follower{/sc} may apply to people who attach themselves either to the person or beliefs of another.
{sc}adherent{/sc} suggests a close and persistent attachment.
{sc}disciple{/sc} implies a devoted allegiance to the teachings of one chosen as a master.
{sc}partisan{/sc} suggests a zealous often prejudiced attachment.

et: Middle English, "follower of Jesus, one of the apostles, pupil," in part going back to Old English {it}discipul,{/it} in part borrowed from Anglo-French {it}disciple,{/it} both borrowed from Late Latin {it}discipulus{/it} "follower of Christ, apostle" (translation of Greek {it}mathētḗs{/it}), going back to Latin, "pupil, learner," of uncertain origin

Traditionally explained as a derivative of {it}discere{/it} "to learn," but the second element {it}-pulus{/it} is neither a known word nor a suffix. According to an alternative explanation, the base is nominalized from an unattested verb {it}*discipere,{/it} putatively, "to grasp, comprehend," from {it}dis-{/it} {et_link|dis-|dis-} and {it}capere{/it} "to take, seize" (cf. {it}disceptāre{/it} "to dispute, debate," supposedly a frequentative from this verb); this is semantically questionable, however, and {it}-ulus{/it} is any case not an agentive suffix.
shortdef: one who accepts and assists in spreading the doctrines of another: such as
one of the twelve in the inner circle of Christ's followers according to the Gospel accounts
a convinced adherent of a school or individual
